rollouts.content:
You are an expert software engineering agent.
Your task is to solve a programming problem.

In order to do this, you are given the following tools.
You must call exactly one tool in every message.

When you are done, check whether your solution works by runinng tests with the following command:

pytest /testbed/tests.py

IMPORTANT: You should only call one tool per system prompt. You should not write a message to the user after you have called the tool, just calling the tool is sufficient.




# Tools

You may call one or more functions to assist with the user query.

You are provided with function signatures within <tools></tools> XML tags:
<tools>
{"type":"function","function":{"name":"bash","description":"Execute bash commands. Separate commands by newlines to execute multiple.","parameters":{"type":"object","properties":{"command":{"type":"string"}},"required":["command"]}}}
{"type":"function","function":{"name":"create_file","description":"Create a file.","parameters":{"type":"object","properties":{"path":{"type":"string","description":"Absolute path to the file."},"content":{"type":"string","description":"Content of the file."}},"required":["path","content"]}}}
{"type":"function","function":{"name":"edit","description":"Edit a file by performing a string replacement.","parameters":{"type":"object","properties":{"path":{"type":"string","description":"Absolute path to the file."},"old_string":{"type":"string","description":"String to be replaced. This exact string should be contained in the file. Note that the string should be indented by exactly as many levels as it is in the file, even if this leads to indenting the whole string."},"new_string":{"type":"string","description":"old_string will be replaced with this string. Note that it should be indented exactly as many layers as it would be in the file, even if this leads to indenting the whole string."},"n_replacements":{"type":"number","description":"Number of replacements to perform. Defaults to 1. This should be the exact number of times that old_string is contained in the file."}},"required":["path","old_string","new_string"]}}}
{"type":"function","function":{"name":"list_directory_contents","description":"List the contents of each file in the given directory. Defaults to showing the direct children of the current working directory.","parameters":{"type":"object","properties":{"path":{"type":"string","description":"Absolute path to the directory. If not specified, the current working directory will be used."},"max_depth":{"type":"number","description":"Maximum depth to search. Defaults to 1 (Show only immediate children of the directory)."}},"required":[]}}}
{"type":"function","function":{"name":"finish","description":"Call this tool when you are finished and you have tested your solution and you are sure that your solution is correct and all the tests pass. Do not call this tool unless you are absolutely sure your solution is correct and you have tested it.","parameters":{"type":"object","properties":{},"required":[]}}}
</tools>

For each function call, return a json object with function name and arguments within <tool_call></tool_call> XML tags:
<tool_call>
{"name": <function-name>, "arguments": <args-json-object>}
</tool_call>

Your goal is to solve the following coding problem.
Please write the solution in a file called /testbed/solution.py.
Do not just write the solution and show it to me - you must use a tool call to put the solution in the /testbed/solution.py file.

Your problem should read the inputs using `input()` and print the outputs using `print(...)`.
It will be executed as is, so it is important not to print anything that is not the output asked for on the given input.
Namely, do not write code that runs the solution on example/demo inputs and do not write debug prints.

=== PROBLEM ===

Vasya has recently finished writing a book. Now he faces the problem of giving it the title. Vasya wants the title to be vague and mysterious for his book to be noticeable among others. That's why the title should be represented by a single word containing at least once each of the first k Latin letters and not containing any other ones. Also, the title should be a palindrome, that is it should be read similarly from the left to the right and from the right to the left.

Vasya has already composed the approximate variant of the title. You are given the title template s consisting of lowercase Latin letters and question marks. Your task is to replace all the question marks by lowercase Latin letters so that the resulting word satisfies the requirements, described above. Each question mark should be replaced by exactly one letter, it is not allowed to delete characters or add new ones to the template. If there are several suitable titles, choose the first in the alphabetical order, for Vasya's book to appear as early as possible in all the catalogues.

Input

The first line contains an integer k (1 ≤ k ≤ 26) which is the number of allowed alphabet letters. The second line contains s which is the given template. In s only the first k lowercase letters of Latin alphabet and question marks can be present, the length of s is from 1 to 100 characters inclusively.

Output

If there is no solution, print IMPOSSIBLE. Otherwise, a single line should contain the required title, satisfying the given template. The title should be a palindrome and it can only contain the first k letters of the Latin alphabet. At that, each of those k letters must be present at least once. If there are several suitable titles, print the lexicographically minimal one. 

The lexicographical comparison is performed by the standard < operator in modern programming languages. The line a is lexicographically smaller than the line b, if exists such an i (1 ≤ i ≤ |s|), that ai < bi, and for any j (1 ≤ j < i) aj = bj. |s| stands for the length of the given template.

Examples

Input

3
a?c


Output

IMPOSSIBLE


Input

2
a??a


Output

abba


Input

2
?b?a


Output

abba

function.name: create_file
function.arguments:
{"path": "/testbed/solution.py", "content": "def solve():
    k = int(input().strip())
    s = input().strip()
    n = len(s)
    
    # The set of allowed characters
    allowed = set(chr(ord('a') + i) for i in range(k))
    
    # Convert s to a list for easier manipulation
    s_list = list(s)
    
    # Check positions for consistency in palindrome
    for i in range((n + 1) // 2):
        left_char = s_list[i]
        right_char = s_list[n - 1 - i]

        if left_char != '?' and right_char != '?' and left_char != right_char:
            print("IMPOSSIBLE")
            return

        if left_char == '?' and right_char == '?':
            # Prefer the smallest allowed character
            s_list[i] = 'a'
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = 'a'
        elif left_char == '?':
            if right_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[i] = right_char
        elif right_char == '?':
            if left_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = left_char
        else:
            # Both are set and equal, but we must check they're allowed
            if left_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return

    # Now check if all required characters are present
    current_chars = set(s_list)
    if not allowed.issubset(current_chars):
        # Try to introduce missing characters from the center outward, ensuring palindrome
        missing = allowed - current_chars
        # Start filling from the middle, preferring changes that don't break palindrome
        for i in range(n // 2, -1, -1):
            # If we can modify this position (i.e., it was originally '?')
            if s[i] == '?' or s[n - 1 - i] == '?':
                while missing:
                    char_to_place = min(missing)
                    # Place the smallest missing character
                    s_list[i] = char_to_place
                    s_list[n - 1 - i] = char_to_place
                    missing.remove(char_to_place)
                    break
            if not missing:
                break

        # However, after this process if still missing, impossible
        if missing:
            print("IMPOSSIBLE")
            return

    # Final check: is it a palindrome and contains all required letters
    if s_list != s_list[::-1] or not allowed.issubset(set(s_list)):
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return

    print(''.join(s_list))

solve()"}

{"path": "/testbed/solution.py", "content": "def solve():
    k = int(input().strip())
    s = input().strip()
    n = len(s)
    
    # The set of allowed characters
    allowed = set(chr(ord('a') + i) for i in range(k))
    
    # Convert s to a list for easier manipulation
    s_list = list(s)
    
    # Check positions for consistency in palindrome
    for i in range((n + 1) // 2):
        left_char = s_list[i]
        right_char = s_list[n - 1 - i]

        if left_char != '?' and right_char != '?' and left_char != right_char:
            print("IMPOSSIBLE")
            return

        if left_char == '?' and right_char == '?':
            # Prefer the smallest allowed character
            s_list[i] = 'a'
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = 'a'
        elif left_char == '?':
            if right_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[i] = right_char
        elif right_char == '?':
            if left_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = left_char
        else:
            # Both are set and equal, but we must check they're allowed
            if left_char not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return

    # Now check if all required characters are present
    current_chars = set(s_list)
    if not allowed.issubset(current_chars):
        # Try to introduce missing characters from the center outward, ensuring palindrome
        missing = allowed - current_chars
        # Start filling from the middle, preferring changes that don't break palindrome
        for i in range(n // 2, -1, -1):
            # If we can modify this position (i.e., it was originally '?')
            if s[i] == '?' or s[n - 1 - i] == '?':
                while missing:
                    char_to_place = min(missing)
                    # Place the smallest missing character
                    s_list[i] = char_to_place
                    s_list[n - 1 - i] = char_to_place
                    missing.remove(char_to_place)
                    break
            if not missing:
                break

        # However, after this process if still missing, impossible
        if missing:
            print("IMPOSSIBLE")
            return

    # Final check: is it a palindrome and contains all required letters
    if s_list != s_list[::-1] or not allowed.issubset(set(s_list)):
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return

    print(''.join(s_list))

solve()"}

content.text:
The current solution has issues in correctly filling the palindrome while ensuring all the first k letters are included and maintaining lexicographical order. We need to fix the logic, especially in introducing missing characters and ensuring the palindrome condition is strictly met.

Let's revise the solution:

1. First, ensure the palindrome property by mirroring known characters.
2. Fill any `?` pairs with the smallest character, 'a', initially.
3. After setting up the palindrome structure, ensure all k letters are present. We will prioritize the center for introducing new characters if needed while preserving the palindrome.
4. Finally, verify the result meets all conditions.

I will correct the solution in `solution.py`.

function.name: create_file
function.arguments:
{"path": "/testbed/solution.py", "content": "def solve():
    k = int(input().strip())
    s = input().strip()
    n = len(s)
    allowed = set(chr(ord('a') + i) for i in range(k))
    s_list = list(s)
    
    # First pass: ensure palindrome structure
    for i in range((n + 1) // 2):
        left = s_list[i]
        right = s_list[n - 1 - i]
        
        if left != '?' and right != '?':
            if left != right:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
        elif left == '?' and right == '?':
            # Prefer the smallest character
            s_list[i] = s_list[n - 1 - i] = 'a'
        elif left == '?':
            if right not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[i] = right
        else:  # right == '?'
            if left not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = left
    
    # Count current characters
    current_chars = set(s_list)
    missing = allowed - current_chars
    
    # Try to fill missing characters starting from the center
    # We traverse from center outwards to minimize lex order impact
    if missing:
        # We need to modify some 'a' (or any) positions to introduce missing characters
        # Modify from the center working outward
        mid = n // 2
        positions = []
        # Collect positions that can be modified (were originally '?' or part of paired '?'s)
        for i in range(mid + 1):
            if s[i] == '?' or s[n - 1 - i] == '?':
                positions.append(i)
        # Sort by distance from center to modify center first
        positions.sort(key=lambda x: abs(x - mid))
        
        for i in positions:
            if not missing:
                break
            # Replace this position with the smallest missing character
            c = min(missing)
            if s_list[i] == 'a':  # Prefer changing 'a' to avoid breaking existing structure
                s_list[i] = s_list[n - 1 - i] = c
                missing.remove(c)
        
    # If still missing any character
    if missing:
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return
    
    # Final palindrome and allowed check
    if s_list != s_list[::-1] or not set(s_list).issuperset(allowed):
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return
    
    print(''.join(s_list))

def run_tests():
    # This function is just to facilitate testing within this environment
    # Actual submission should only contain solve()
    pass

def run_solution(input_str):
    import sys
    from io import StringIO
    old_stdin = sys.stdin
    sys.stdin = StringIO(input_str)
    old_stdout = sys.stdout
    sys.stdout = captured_output = StringIO()
    try:
        solve()
    finally:
        sys.stdin = old_stdin
        sys.stdout = old_stdout
    return captured_output.getvalue().strip()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    solve()"}

{"path": "/testbed/solution.py", "content": "def solve():
    k = int(input().strip())
    s = input().strip()
    n = len(s)
    allowed = set(chr(ord('a') + i) for i in range(k))
    s_list = list(s)
    
    # First pass: ensure palindrome structure
    for i in range((n + 1) // 2):
        left = s_list[i]
        right = s_list[n - 1 - i]
        
        if left != '?' and right != '?':
            if left != right:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
        elif left == '?' and right == '?':
            # Prefer the smallest character
            s_list[i] = s_list[n - 1 - i] = 'a'
        elif left == '?':
            if right not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[i] = right
        else:  # right == '?'
            if left not in allowed:
                print("IMPOSSIBLE")
                return
            s_list[n - 1 - i] = left
    
    # Count current characters
    current_chars = set(s_list)
    missing = allowed - current_chars
    
    # Try to fill missing characters starting from the center
    # We traverse from center outwards to minimize lex order impact
    if missing:
        # We need to modify some 'a' (or any) positions to introduce missing characters
        # Modify from the center working outward
        mid = n // 2
        positions = []
        # Collect positions that can be modified (were originally '?' or part of paired '?'s)
        for i in range(mid + 1):
            if s[i] == '?' or s[n - 1 - i] == '?':
                positions.append(i)
        # Sort by distance from center to modify center first
        positions.sort(key=lambda x: abs(x - mid))
        
        for i in positions:
            if not missing:
                break
            # Replace this position with the smallest missing character
            c = min(missing)
            if s_list[i] == 'a':  # Prefer changing 'a' to avoid breaking existing structure
                s_list[i] = s_list[n - 1 - i] = c
                missing.remove(c)
        
    # If still missing any character
    if missing:
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return
    
    # Final palindrome and allowed check
    if s_list != s_list[::-1] or not set(s_list).issuperset(allowed):
        print("IMPOSSIBLE")
        return
    
    print(''.join(s_list))

def run_tests():
    # This function is just to facilitate testing within this environment
    # Actual submission should only contain solve()
    pass

def run_solution(input_str):
    import sys
    from io import StringIO
    old_stdin = sys.stdin
    sys.stdin = StringIO(input_str)
    old_stdout = sys.stdout
    sys.stdout = captured_output = StringIO()
    try:
        solve()
    finally:
        sys.stdin = old_stdin
        sys.stdout = old_stdout
    return captured_output.getvalue().strip()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    solve()"}
